conclusion: The problem involves maximizing the power-source output efficiency.
Efficiency is defined as the ratio of the power delivered to the load to the power supplied by the source.
The power supplied by the source is given by \\( P_{\text{source}} = V_{\text{source}} \cdot I_{\text{source}} \\).
The power delivered to the load is given by \\( P_{\text{load}} = V_{\text{load}} \cdot I_{\text{load}} \\).
The efficiency (\\(\eta\\)) of the circuit is then \\( \eta = \frac{P_{\text{load}}}{P_{\text{source}}} = \frac{V_{\text{load}} \cdot I_{\text{load}}}{V_{\text{source}} \cdot I_{\text{source}}} \\).
To maximize the efficiency, we need to maximize the power delivered to the load relative to the power supplied by the source.
This typically occurs when the load resistance matches the internal resistance of the power source, which is known as the maximum power transfer theorem.
The graph shows the terminal voltage and current of the power source and resistors \\( R_1 \\) and \\( R_2 \\).
The power source has a terminal voltage of 3V when no current is drawn.
The slope of the line representing the power source is -0.5 \\(\Omega\\).
For resistor \\( R_1 \\), the graph shows a linear relationship with a slope of 0.5, indicating \\( R_1 = 0.5 \Omega \\).
For resistor \\( R_2 \\), the graph shows a linear relationship with a slope of 1, indicating \\( R_2 = 1 \Omega \\).
The optimal configuration to maximize the power-source output efficiency is to connect \\( R_1 \\) in parallel with the power source.
Connecting \\( R_1 \\) in parallel with the power source will result in a lower effective resistance, thus maximizing the power delivered to the load and hence the efficiency.
